season_summary.narrative: Two weeks produced clear early separation: three unbeaten teams at 2-0, three winless at 0-2, and a large middle group at 1-1 with several high-scoring rosters. League scoring is high and volatile; managers repeatedly left large scores on benches and several teams swung >40 points week-to-week based on a few players. QB/RB big weeks and D/ST/kicker anomalies produced decisive swings.

team_trends.scoring_pattern: High-floor offense across both weeks (149.8 then 92.88); balanced WR and QB production drove wins.
notable_team_notes: Week 1 explosion (149.8) led by multiple WRs exceeding projection; Week 2 closer win but still above average.
Has the league-best 2-game winning streak; solid points-for suggests staying power.

team_trends.team: If Ur Not First You're Last
team_trends.scoring_pattern: Very high-scoring team (99.82 then 145.78). Reliant on a top WR pairing in Week 2 and a strong Mahomes week.
notable_team_notes: Big Week 2 receiving outburst (Malik Nabers 37.7, Rome Odunze 31.8) keyed a 2-point win.
One of the highest-scoring teams across two weeks; offensive ceiling is among the league best.

team_trends.scoring_pattern: Consistently above average (102.22 then 133.8); meaningful TE and WR weeks plus deep bench scoring.
notable_team_notes: Tucker Kraft and Davante Adams produced huge Week 2 contributions; bench Wan'Dale Robinson (28.2) was a major unused asset.
Strong roster depth evidenced by large unused bench points.

team_trends.scoring_pattern: Large swings driven by RB/WR big weeks and volatile QB/RB outcomes (Henry 29.2 then 2.3).
notable_team_notes: Week 1 dominant (135.12) then narrow Week 2 loss (89.72); Javonte Williams produced two large games (20.4 bench week, 25.0 starter week).
Roster has upside but inconsistent outcomes from lead RB.

team_trends.scoring_pattern: High ceiling driven by elite WR performance (Amon-Ra St. Brown 39.2 in Week 2); QB and other pass-catchers have been volatile.
notable_team_notes: Huge one-point Week 2 win thanks to Amon-Ra's 39.2; Jalen Hurts underperformed week-to-week.
Points-for places them among the stronger 1-1 teams.

team_trends.scoring_pattern: Rookie QB/RB upside and above-projection RB days; one lopsided loss then bounce-back by rookie pieces.
notable_team_notes: Benched Michael Penix Jr. (24.02 in W1) in Week 1 — costly decision noted.
De'Von Achane and Drake Maye combined for a strong Week 2 showing.

team_trends.scoring_pattern: Highest points-for across two weeks (141.46 then 119.2); balanced superstar performances (Lamar Jackson, CMC) but still split results.
notable_team_notes: Elite two-week scoring total driven by Lamar Jackson and Christian McCaffrey; lost a narrow Week 2 matchup (119.2 vs 120.64) despite strong total.
Bench pieces (Trevor Lawrence, Rachaad White) provided scoring that in some weeks was left unused.

team_trends.scoring_pattern: RB-centric offense (Bijan Robinson produced) but inconsistent WR/TE production (Pickens down week 1 then big week 2).
notable_team_notes: Bijan Robinson was a reliable source (24.4 then 19.8); Breece Hall underperformed in Week 2.
Still building consistency despite RB success.

team_trends.scoring_pattern: Low-to-mid scoring with volatile WR outcomes; Week 2 bounce after Week 1 blowout loss.
notable_team_notes: Week 1 bench miscues (Daniel Jones 29.48 and Keenan Allen 19.8 left on bench) in a large loss; Week 2 used Dak + Kenneth Walker to win.
Bench management was a major factor in Week 1 loss.

team_trends.scoring_pattern: Low total in Week 2 (60.2) after a solid Week 1; defense outperformance in Week 1 offset some offensive struggles.
notable_team_notes: Broncos D/ST delivered a huge Week 1 boost (16.0); Week 2 saw a critical benching error (Jared Goff 33.96 left inactive) and multiple underperforming pass-catchers.
Roster volatility and lineup mistakes have materially impacted outcomes.

team_trends.scoring_pattern: Extremely high points-for (123.82 then 142.78); elite single-week ceilings, driven by stellar WR/TE weeks.
notable_team_notes: Week 2 produced a 142.78 output including Ja'Marr Chase (36.5) and James Cook (26.5); large bench kicker and QB points (Brandon Aubrey 22.0, Jordan Love 20.88) were left unused.
Despite the Week 2 loss, total scoring makes them a dangerous team moving forward.

team_trends.scoring_pattern: Week 1 monster (122.36) then closer Week 2 (102.62); huge Week 1 Josh Allen performance followed by an underperformance from Allen in Week 2.
notable_team_notes: Josh Allen (38.76) carried Week 1 but underperformed Week 2 (11.82); Justin Fields produced a big bench score in Week 1 (29.52) but was unused.
Defense (Seahawks D/ST Week 2) provided a major swing in Week 2.

team_trends.scoring_pattern: Struggling offense across both weeks with multiple high-profile WR/TE busts (A.J. Brown, Mark Andrews, Xavier Worthy).
notable_team_notes: 0-2 start and severely underperforming projections; Mark Andrews and A.J. Brown both posted low outputs versus expectations.
Hasn't found reliable weekly scoring yet.

team_trends.scoring_pattern: Low scoring with large losses; repeatedly left high-scoring bench QBs/TEs (Aaron Rodgers, Dalton Kincaid) unused in Week 1.
notable_team_notes: Benched Aaron Rodgers (25.66) and Dalton Kincaid (14.8) in Week 1 — major missed points.
Underperformance from key WRs (Justin Jefferson) contributed to two losses.

team_trends.scoring_pattern: Good single-player games (Jonathan Taylor 29.5) but inconsistent complementary scoring and costly benching (Keon Coleman Week 1 bench 25.2).
notable_team_notes: Lost both weeks despite exploitative single-player weeks; benching of Keon Coleman (25.2) in Week 1 noted as season-altering decision.
Needs more consistent multi-player output.

team_trends.scoring_pattern: Strong receiving core (Puka Nacua 23.1 then 27.6) and bench depth that sometimes remains unused but overall positive outputs.
notable_team_notes: Large Week 2 win (137.82) powered by Puka Nacua and Jameson Williams; bench Jauan Jennings (19.9) was notable but unused.
Team shows upward scoring trajectory.

player_trends.trend: Repeat top performer (29.36 in Week 1, 26.3 in Week 2). Consistent high ceiling from rushing and passing — a primary scoring engine for his team.
Back-to-back top outputs (23.2 then 22.7) — reliable RB production contributing to highest team PF.
Two strong weeks (23.1 then 27.6) — reliable WR target with rising role and consistent fantasy impact.
Boom week in Week 1 (28.1) followed by solid Week 2 (14.9) — early-season WR outperformer for a 2-0 team.
Extreme week-to-week volatility: underperformed in Week 1 (8.5) then exploded in Week 2 (39.2) producing a one-game outcome swing.
Massive Week 1 (38.76) followed by a subpar Week 2 (11.82) — demonstrates QB volatility and dependence on single-week blowups.
Huge Week 1 (29.2) and then a major bust Week 2 (2.3) — large variance from week to week that affected team record.

impacted_teams: If Ur Not First You're Last
player_trends.trend: Both produced massive Week 2 outputs (Nabers 37.7, Odunze 31.8) and were the primary drivers of a runaway Week 2 total; they represent a high-ceiling WR pairing.
Big bounceback from a low Week 1 (4.6) to Week 2 monster (36.5) — highlights volatility and high upside.

average_scoring.note: Average team score ~108 points per week across first two weeks; several teams well above that and multiple games exceeded typical weekly averages.

close_games.note: High-scoring one-point game decided by a single WR performance.

close_games.matchup: If Ur Not First You're Last vs Team Santangelo (Week 2)
close_games.note: Two-point, extremely high combined scoring game (288.56 combined).

close_games.matchup: Jake Butt Stuff vs THE Derbaum (Week 2)
close_games.note: Close 3-point margin influenced by RB/QB swings and bench decisions.

blowouts_and_lopsided_results_examples.matchup: SnydeRemarks vs Big Trouble in Little Cameron (Week 1)
blowouts_and_lopsided_results_examples.note: Large margin powered by multiple starters far exceeding projection.

blowouts_and_lopsided_results_examples.matchup: Team Santangelo vs Xavier Marks the Spot (Week 1)
blowouts_and_lopsided_results_examples.note: One-sided game with several starters underperforming for the losing side.

bench_impact_summary.observation: Early weeks have seen numerous high-value benchings that changed outcomes; examples include Daniel Jones (29.48), Wan'Dale Robinson (28.2), Jared Goff (33.96), Keon Coleman (25.2), Aaron Rodgers (25.66), and Michael Penix Jr. (24.02) left unused in various matchups.
bench_impact_summary.implication: Bench management and activation of unexpectedly large-scoring players have been decisive in many match results.

league_insights.projection_vs_actual_notes: Multiple teams both over and underperformed aggregate projections; kickers and D/ST swings (e.g., Broncos D/ST 16.0, Colts D/ST 14.0, Steelers D/ST underperforming) created outsized effects in some matches.

players_benched.note: Left on bench in Week 1; would have materially changed outcome.
Also benched in Week 1 contributing to a large unused point total.

examples.note: Week 2 benching of a 28.2-point player reduced an already large score potential.
QB left inactive in Week 2 while Brock Purdy was listed Inactive; large missed opportunity.
Benched in Week 1 and likely swung that matchup result.

owner_behaviors.behavior: Risky starts/lineups with low-projection but high variance players

examples.note: Started some rookie/high-upside pieces that paid off (Drake Maye, De'Von Achane), demonstrating a risk-on approach that produced immediate gains.

examples.team: Teams starting kickers or D/ST with volatile projections
examples.note: Several managers benefited from unexpectedly high kicker/DST weeks (e.g., Brandon Aubrey 22.0 on bench; Colts D/ST 14.0 started) while others were burned by negative D/ST returns.
Heavy dependence on Josh Allen produced one massive win and one weaker week; roster depth produced large bench QBs (Justin Fields) who were unused but showed overall strength.

playoff_projection.format_assumed: Top 6 teams make playoffs (ranked by record, then head-to-head, then Points For).

projected_playoff_teams_and_seeds.team: If Ur Not First You're Last
projected_playoff_teams_and_seeds.rationale: 2-0 with 245.6 points-for (highest among the 2-0 group), strong Week 2 WR outburst.
2-0 with 242.68 points-for; consistent production across both weeks.
2-0 with 236.02 points-for; deep roster and two wins to start season.
Top Points For among 1-1 teams (266.6) — tiebreak advantages via PF place them into playoff slots despite 1-1 record.
Second-highest PF among 1-1 teams (260.66); very strong two-week scoring despite 1-1 split.
Next highest PF among 1-1 teams (231.62) and a decisive Week 2 one-point win driven by an elite WR performance.

notes_and_risks: Three 2-0 teams occupy the top seeds purely on record; several 1-1 teams have higher points-for than some 2-0 teams but lose on record-based tiebreakers.

Early-season volatility (huge single-player weeks, bench swings) means playoff projections are provisional; managers with high PF but a 1-1 record (Team Santangelo, SnydeRemarks) are well-positioned to claim late-season playoff seats if they tighten lineup management.
Head-to-head tiebreakers haven't resolved multi-way ties; future head-to-head results will be crucial among the large 1-1 group.
